awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Geographic and Temporal Homicide Dynamics 1870-2003
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine historical changes in the location and prevalence of homicide in three U.S. cities from 1870 to the present. By digitizing and geocoding homicide data from over a century, this project will create new measures to describe the geographic and temporal dynamics of homicide such as change in homicide hotspots: size, lifespan, and rate of occurrence. This quantitative historical analysis enables exploration of whether homicide dynamics today are the continuation of a historical pattern or the product of recent changes in U.S. society. More broadly, this project will advance the fields of sociology, law, and criminology by testing whether existing theories can help identify events triggering or diminishing change in homicide's location, timing, and prevalence. Data will come from historical archives in Chicago, New Orleans, and San Francisco, and the project will unfold in two stages. First, a research team and laboratory will be assembled to digitize and geocode archival materials. Second, the research team will use the digitized data to examine research questions including but not limited to: A) did major scientific advances in homicide investigation techniques decrease homicide's prevalence? B) do events that erode community trust in police trigger homicide waves? C) do events that trigger sentiments of collective efficacy diminish homicide hotspots lifespan or rate-of-occurrence? Quasi-experimental research methods such as comparative interrupted time series and regression discontinuity models will be used to assess these questions. 

	With respect to broader impacts, this project will help cities improve network and place-based homicide prevention efforts by identifying the ideal timing and duration for law enforcement and social service interventions. Similarly, the identification of events that trigger homicide waves may help cities learn how to anticipate sudden increases in violence. Finally, the project will make use of a novel method for disseminating project findings to the greater public. Through collaborations with a data visualization scientist as well as local libraries in Chicago, New Orleans, and San Francisco, project findings will be shared with the public through displays of large maps visualizing change in historical homicide patterns. Project maps and data visualizations will be displayed in libraries and galleries in each city to spark greater public interest and awareness about homicide and the science of prevention.

por.por_cntn:
In 2017, the National Science Foundation awarded Professor Robert Vargas with an Early Career Development (CAREER) Award for a project titled “The Evolution of Homicide Hotspots Over the 20th Century: A Three City Study.” This project was designed to investigate homicide trends in Chicago, New Orleans, and San Francisco from 1870 to the present, with the goal of creating new measures to describe geographic and temporal homicide dynamics, and ultimately help cities improve network and place-based homicide prevention efforts.

During the funding period, Professor Vargas’s team digitized Chicago ward boundaries from 1837 to 2015 and digitized homicide datasets in Chicago and New Orleans from 1870 to the present. The digitization of Chicago’s ward boundaries paved the way for a historical analysis of redistricting, specifically looking at the extent at which the manipulation of political space is racially or economically motivated. Due to travel complications created by the COVID 19 pandemic, further digitization of ward-equivalent boundaries was completed for two additional midwestern cities: Milwaukee and St. Louis. This work resulted in the publication of a Social Problems article titled “The Racial and Economic Foundations of Municipal Redistricting,” which traced the movement of wards after each city’s wards were redrawn by measuring the distance traveled by ward’s centroid. The digitization of homicide data in Chicago from 1870 to the present allowed for the production of homicide rates by community area, which were calculated using population counts from censuses and linear interpolation to estimate population counts between decennial censuses. This work resulted in an article published in The University of Chicago Law Review  titled “Capitalizing on Crisis: Chicago Responses to Homicide Waves 1920-2020,” which identified four major peaks in homicides in Chicago and detailed the City of Chicago’s monopolization of crime data to influence the public discourse. Professor Vargas has presented this work to public officials in Chicago, Cook County, and the Illinois state legislature, as well as at several philanthropic foundations and community based organizations. The research has informed policymakers and philanthropic organizations strategies with respect to pursuing public safety innovation. 

In Fall of 2022, Professor Vargas acquired handwritten death records form 1940-1964 from the Cook County Medical Examiner’s Office. A team of five undergraduate research assistants has been systematically digitizing these records—scanning through each certificate, only digitizing records whose cause of death or verdict are homicide-related. The team used a spreadsheet tracking system to distribute the labor of digitizing over 280 scanned books (many of which contain more than 300 pages each), and to keep tabs on progress. The team meets regularly on a bi-weekly basis to discuss observed trends, pose investigating questions, and flag problems or discrepancies in digitizing the historical records.

Professor Vargas’s team will continue to publish work using this data in the years to come. They will do so by merging digitized homicide records with data from the Zillow Transaction and Assessment Database (ZTRAX), which will enable them to use buildings data as a proxy for population, in order to produce census level tract estimates of homicide rates dating back to 1870 in Chicago, San Francisco, and New Orleans.

The work produced, and to be produced by this project is of immense academic and social importance as it will generate awareness about homicide and the science of violence prevention and can aid cities’ intervention and prevention strategies through an understanding of events that have previously triggered homicide waves. 

Publications produced from this grant include:

Vargas, Robert, Chris Williams, Philip O’Sullivan, and Christina Cano. 2022 “Capitalizing on Crisis: Chicago Responses to Homicide Waves 1920-2020.” University of Chicago Law Review. 89: 405-439.

Vargas, Robert, Christina Cano, Paola Del Toro, and Brian Fenaughty. 2021. “The Racial and Economic Foundations of Municipal Redistricting.” Social Problems.
